course_title: Photography from the Daguerrotype to Instagram

learning_outcomes.description: Understand fundamental critical debates in the History of Photography and recognize some of the key practitioners in the field
be familiar with a number of the key works and artists of the History of Photography
have an awareness of the important critical issues surrounding Photography
consider Photography from a number of different historical and philosophical perspectives
form your own opinions about photo-based images and the issues raised by them
respond to and describe key works in the History of Photography
be familiar with the ways photographs can be viewed as historical evidence
be familiar with the history of Australia as refracted through the prism of Photography

assessments.assessment_title: Seminar Preparation, Participation and Worksheet Completion
assessments.weighting: <dd>20% Each worksheet is worth 2% of final grade </dd>
assessments.task_description:
From weeks 2 to 12 (excluding the reading weeks) you will be given 2 marks (equals 2 percentage points) for each week that you:

1. are prepared for (that is, you have done the readings and brought these to the seminar). These will be checked;

2. attend and participate for the entirety of lecture and tutorial (so turning up on time and staying till the finish); and

3. complete a writing task of passable standard to your tutor after each tutorial. For the writing task you write a response to a question based on that week's readings. 10 worksheets with short questions on aspects of the lecture and readings will be distributed at the beginning of tutorials across the semester. The worksheets with be completed individually during the tutorial and handed in directly to the tutor at the end of class. Worksheets are graded as pass/fail. 

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your response to the weekly worksheet directly to the tutor at the end of the tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
3/04/2025 1:30 pm

To be completed in person in timetabled lecture time.
assessments.task_description:
This is an in-class timed test held on Week 6 during the lecture. Students will have 1.5 hours in total to respond to a set of questions based on the course images, lectures, readings and tutorials until Week 5 included. The format of the assessment is short answer.

The assessment will be marked against these evenly weighted criteria:

  • Ability to reference the readings and lectures content;
  • Ability to reference visual objects to support your argument;
  • Articulation of argument that responds to the question;
  • Coherent essay structure that prioritises key points;
  • High standard of written expression;
  • Excellent grammar and spelling

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment will be submitted in class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This in-person final examination will cover readings and other materials discussed in the entire course.

The examination has four questions requiring you to write a short essay in response. Each essay is worth 10 marks (or 10 per cent of your marks for the course).

Essay topics may include a visual analysis of a supplied image.

Suggested length for each essay: between 500-750 words in length, including quotations.

You can make reference to any of the required readings from the course reading list. No other primary or secondary sources (e.g other critical readings of texts) are required.

The assessment will be marked against these evenly weighted criteria:

  • Ability to reference the readings and lectures content;
  • Ability to reference visual objects to support your argument;
  • Articulation of argument that responds to the question;
  • Coherent essay structure that prioritises key points;
  • High standard of written expression;
  • Excellent grammar and spelling

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: UQ is presently rolling out a new assessment tool, Inspera Assessment. Inspera Assessment provides additional functionality to complement the existing suite of digital learning tools at UQ with a greater range of question types and accessibility provisions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
